title: Enterocutaneous Fistula
setup_script: “A 55-year-old woman develops a draining wound on her abdomen 10 days after a complicated bowel resection for Crohn’s disease. The output is high volume and appears like intestinal contents. How would you proceed?”

dynamic_flow.reply: BP 110/70 mmHg, HR 105 bpm, RR 18/min, Temp 38 °C.
Effluent of 800 mL/day of bilious fluid from midline incision; surrounding skin excoriated and erythematous.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident asks about fistula output

dynamic_flow.reply: Blood cultures obtained, broad-spectrum antibiotics started.
CT scan shows intra-abdominal collection adjacent to anastomosis.
Octreotide may be considered though evidence is mixed.
Stoma appliance and skin barrier applied; enterostomal therapy nurse consulted.
CT enterography shows no distal obstruction.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident asks about timing of surgery
dynamic_flow.reply: Fistula persists after 4 months of optimization; elective resection/anastomosis is planned.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident rushes to early surgery
dynamic_flow.reply: Operation complicated by dense adhesions and malnutrition; recurrence risk is high.
Patient counseled regarding long-term plan, nutritional support, and emotional impact.

critical_decision_points: Sepsis control and source identification with imaging/drainage.
Timing of definitive surgery after resolution of inflammation and optimization.
Comprehensive wound care and psychosocial support.

resident_feedback_template: Strengths:You demonstrated strong diagnostic reasoning by recognizing the high-output enterocutaneous fistula promptly. Your management of sepsis and initiation of nutritional optimization were appropriate. Communication with the patient and interdisciplinary team was clear and compassionate.Areas for Improvement:Earlier emphasis on evaluating distal obstruction and establishing criteria for surgical timing would strengthen your clinical judgment.
